Central Banking (Federal Reserve Monetar.time_to_resolution: About 2 months (question likely resolves with publication of the November 2025 CPI data in mid-December 2025)
Central Banking (Federal Reserve Monetar.perspective_relevance: As a central banking (Federal Reserve monetary policy) expert, my approach emphasizes the link between lagged monetary policy changes and inflation outcomes, the mechanics of policy transmission, and the ways in which exogenous shocks (e.g., tariffs, fiscal stimuli, labor supply shifts) interact with aggregate demand and supply. I am attuned to base rates in inflation deceleration after prior spikes, the capacity of the Fed's current stance to offset supply-side shocks, and how political dynamics can (or cannot) sustain changes in inflation trajectories.
Central Banking (Federal Reserve Monetar.status_quo: The 12-month US CPI inflation rate as of November 2024 is 2.73%. Over the last year, inflation has been generally trending upwards, influenced by tariffs and supply shocks, though more slowly than feared. If nothing changes—policy remains loose, tariffs stay; weak labor market persists—trend is for slight further increases in YoY CPI.

perspective_derived_factors.effect: DECREASES probability. Historically, when inflation rises on tariffs, it tends to exhibit persistence for several quarters; one-year dips are rare barring aggressive tightening or negative demand shocks. When inflation rises materially above target, it usually takes more than a year to turn sustainably down.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Monetary Policy Reaction Function (Interest Rate Cuts Amid Above-Target Inflation)
perspective_derived_factors.effect: DECREASES probability. The Fed is moving toward easier monetary policy even with inflation above target. Easier policy tends to support demand, slowing any disinflation unless there is an overwhelming negative demand shock elsewhere.

DECREASES probability. Most evidence now shows tariffs are lifting price levels directly and, with time, becoming more fully passed through as businesses run out of buffers. While some absorption remains, each additional quarter likely sees higher CPI, all else equal.

INCREASES probability. Substantial job market weakness (large negative revisions to payrolls, rising unemployment, multi-sigma jobless claims) may lead to a demand-driven drop in inflation later in 2025, as labor slack grows and wage growth falls, curtailing consumption.

NEUTRAL; context-dependent. If Fed and market consensus is correct that tariffs are mostly a 'one-off' price shock, and ex-tariff CPI decelerates after the initial jump, then inflation could recede by late 2025. But evidence is mixed: pass-through appears ongoing, and there's little to suggest this is entirely 'one and done'.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Global and Domestic Fiscal Policy Shifts
perspective_derived_factors.effect: DECREASES probability. Evidence of continued or increased fiscal impulse through tax cuts or spending tends to support aggregate demand, further offsetting any disinflation pressure from labor market slack.
INCREASES uncertainty, but if recent CPI surges prove to be temporary (e.g., sharp gasoline or food price shocks unwinding), possible the YoY rate dips even without major macro changes.

Central Banking (Federal Reserve Monetar.no_scenario: Inflation persists or rises further through November 2025 due to continued pass-through of tariffs, renewed energy price pressure, firm aggregate demand as the economy stabilizes post-rate-cut, and only moderate softening in consumer spending. Year-on-year CPI ends November 2025 at or above 2.73%, as base effects from 2024's lower inflation numbers drop out and more of the 2025 increases are incorporated.
Central Banking (Federal Reserve Monetar.yes_scenario: A rapid and continuing labor market cooling (with pronounced weakness in hiring and layoffs) reduces household incomes and spending sufficiently to overwhelm tariff-driven inflation, perhaps augmented by a sharp pullback in consumer and business sentiment or negative shock abroad, leading to sequentially declining monthly price increases. By November 2025, YoY CPI inflation edges below the prior year’s 2.73%, perhaps understated by unwinding of earlier supply spikes.
Central Banking (Federal Reserve Monetar.final_reasoning: Base rates indicate that once inflation pops above target due to exogenous cost shocks (tariffs, labor market supply drops), it is normally persistent through the next year unless monetary policy is substantially tightened or a major demand shock materializes. The Federal Reserve is about to ease policy even with CPI >2.7% (August: 2.9%). Tariff effects are still flowing through, and while some price gains are absorbed by margins, there’s evidence this buffering is increasingly limited as 2025 progresses. The policy impulse from Trump (tariff, fiscal, immigration) remains inflationary in the short run. On the disinflationary side, recent data show a shockingly weak labor market with much higher unemployment and subdued job growth, implying real demand may soon falter. Some PPI and core inflation data are coming in cooler than expected, and there are signs—if the labor market deteriorates further—that headline CPI could decelerate into late 2025. That said, the bulk of mainstream projections (CBO, Moody’s) expect 2025 inflation to exceed 2024. Thus, while upside and downside risks exist, the status quo—moderately above-target inflation, even amid labor market slack—should be weighted more heavily. I therefore assign a probability notably below 50%, but not near-zero, for a YoY CPI inflation rate in November 2025 below November 2024’s 2.73%.

Central Banking (Fed Forward Guidance).time_to_resolution: About 2 months (today: 2025-09-15; reference outcome: November 2025 CPI YoY vs November 2024)
Central Banking (Fed Forward Guidance).perspective_relevance: As an expert in central banking with a focus on Fed forward guidance, I have deep familiarity with how monetary policy, labor market dynamics, and government signaling (including US presidents’ attempts to influence the Fed) interact with inflation over short/medium timeframes. I pay especially close attention to how policy lags, base effects, and the transmission mechanism from policy changes to realized inflation play out, alongside the practicalities of how transitory shocks (e.g., tariffs, immigration policy) might or might not be allowed to 'pass through' to consumer prices.
Central Banking (Fed Forward Guidance).status_quo: If current tendencies persist, CPI inflation is running just under 3% YoY, with moderate upside risks from tariffs and downside risks from slowing labor demand. The status quo would likely see the YoY CPI for November 2025 not much changed from November 2024 (2.73%), possibly a bit higher if policy supports growth or tariffs pass fully to final demand, or lower if labor market weakening accelerates.

perspective_derived_factors.effect: Increases probability of higher inflation through fall 2025 compared to a year prior, as tariffs imposed in 2025 may only gradually filter into consumer prices, especially on goods like autos and clothes (per recent CPI breakdowns); however, the bulk of immediate tariff pass-through often occurs in first ~6-9 months (i.e., mostly by summer/fall 2025).

Decreases probability of sustained inflation above the 2024 level as unemployment climbs, payroll growth slows, and risk of recession or 'labor recession' rises—historically, demand-side weakness reliably tempers core inflation within 3–6 quarters, and the jobs data (downward revisions, weak August print) suggest slack building will persist.

Increases odds of inflation staying elevated if real rates get cut more than justified by supply-side constraints, but the actual pace of rate cuts appears measured; market-implied path is for perhaps two cuts by end of 2025, not an aggressive easing cycle, with the Fed signaling comfort treating tariff shock as 'one-time.' Thus, modest downward pressure from easier policy, but not enough to override slowing demand.

Increases odds of a lower YoY inflation print in 2025: Because headline CPI rose in late 2024 (especially post-election), it will be easier for 2025 to print below 2.73% if inflation slows or plateaus even modestly.
Increases inflation by boosting demand (tax cuts, rebates), but effects are lagging and may be offset by tighter private spending due to job loss/population decline.

Reduces labor supply and puts upward pressure on wages/costs above baseline, but this is counteracted by outright population loss and weak job creation, leading net effect to be ambiguous to slightly inflationary.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Producer Price Index (PPI) and Intermediate Input Absorption
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Lowers the risk of persistent inflation, as recent PPI data are soft and suggest that businesses are absorbing rather than fully passing through import costs, reducing the mechanical tariff-to-consumer price linkage.

Central Banking (Fed Forward Guidance).no_scenario: If tariff pass-through is more persistent than anticipated, or if fiscal stimulus and labor market tightness drive a significant wage-price spiral—even in the face of labor market weakening—then the November 2025 CPI YoY print could match or exceed the already-elevated November 2024 print (>2.73%). For example, continuous shocks to goods prices (energy, food, autos) and/or reversal of Fed rate cuts if inflation scare hits could keep inflation sticky above target.
Central Banking (Fed Forward Guidance).yes_scenario: If labor market weakness deepens (driven by high unemployment benefit claims, negative job revisions, and weak payrolls), consumer demand slows, and much of the tariff-related price shock proves to be a one-off (with PPI and CPI month-over-month prints moderating into Q4), then year-on-year inflation in November 2025 will come in below the November 2024 figure—likely even more so if oil/food prices stabilize. If the US economy enters a mild ('labor') recession, then CPI could drift well below current levels, reflecting the classic late-cycle disinflation.
Central Banking (Fed Forward Guidance).final_reasoning: Taking all factors together: (1) The base rate is that US CPI inflation usually mean reverts after a positive shock unless the shock is repeated or continually reinforced. (2) Most recent rapid inflation upcycles have ended with subsequent YoY prints lower than the prior year, especially when labor markets turn decisively negative. (3) The stickiness of recent tariff-driven inflation is real, but business absorption and evidence from the PPI suggest this shock is dissipating, not compounding. (4) Fed policy is not aggressively stimulative; forward guidance indicates a moderate easing path, and real rates remain structurally positive. (5) Economic consensus and models (CBO, Moody’s) forecast 2025 inflation modestly above 3% for the full year, but CPI already peaked above 2.7% in mid-2025, raising the bar for a higher November-to-November number. (6) News consensus and labor data suggest that recession risk/demand-driven disinflation outweighs the risk of another inflation surge barring an energy shock or further supply chain breakdowns. Therefore, the most likely outcome is a headline CPI YoY in November 2025 that is below the November 2024 value of 2.73%, probably in the 2.0–2.6% range. My uncertainty is modest: while not a lock, the weight of labor market data, policy reaction, and absorption of tariff shocks make a 'Yes' outcome—lower inflation in November 2025—significantly more probable than a 'No.' I judge a 73% chance inflation in November 2025 YoY will be lower than November 2024’s level.

US Economic Statistics (Bureau of Labor.time_to_resolution: Approximately 2 months until November 2025 CPI data is published (as of September 15, 2025).
US Economic Statistics (Bureau of Labor.perspective_relevance: As an expert in US Economic Statistics and the Bureau of Labor Statistics (BLS) CPI methodology, I bring specialized knowledge in how CPI is compiled, interpreted, and the typical paths of inflation in response to factors such as tariffs, monetary policy, labor market shifts, and one-off price shocks. This expertise allows me to analyze not only the economic trends, but also the nuances of how policy and macro conditions filter through into CPI calculations and 12-month change metrics.
US Economic Statistics (Bureau of Labor.status_quo: The 12-month percent change in CPI as of November 2024 was 2.73%. Recent data show the rate has risen to 2.9% as of August 2025. If ongoing trends persist without further shocks, the 12-month change is likely to stay flat or rise moderately through late 2025.

perspective_derived_factors.effect: Increases probability of higher inflation (No outcome) because while first-order pass through appears muted and some foreign firms are absorbing costs, recent CPI data indicate tariff-driven price rises are now filtering through to core goods prices.

Increases probability of lower inflation (Yes outcome) over the coming months, as sharply reduced job gains and higher unemployment are likely to weigh on wage growth and consumer demand, potentially offsetting tariff effects.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Fed interest rate policy and political pressure
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Slightly increases probability of lower inflation (Yes outcome), as rate cuts tend to stimulate the economy but, with weak labor demand, are less likely to stoke a major rebound; ongoing political interference creates policy uncertainty but the Fed is still perceived as acting moderately.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Base effects in annual CPI calculation
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Neutral to mildly increases probability of lower inflation (Yes outcome), as the CPI rose around 2.7–2.9% in the preceding 12 months, so a single month of flat or negative MoM prints closer to November 2025 could lower the YoY change, even if average monthly prints remain positive.

Increases probability of higher inflation (No outcome), as the contraction in labor supply (due to immigration restrictions) feeds into higher service sector labor costs and pushes up prices, but this is counteracted by weaker population growth and reduced aggregate demand.

Slightly increases probability of lower inflation (Yes outcome), since consensus among policymakers is that most tariff/price rises are one-off and not persistent, making it harder for inflation to sustain upward acceleration barring new shocks.

US Economic Statistics (Bureau of Labor.no_scenario: Inflation continues to rise due to cumulative tariff pass-through, persistent elevated service sector wage growth (perhaps reflecting demographic constraints), and potential supply-side bottlenecks. Even as the labor market slows, core goods and shelter prices do not cool quickly enough, keeping the 12-month CPI growth in November 2025 >= 2.73%. Rate cuts fail to spur demand but do little to control cost-push factors.
US Economic Statistics (Bureau of Labor.yes_scenario: Labor demand weakens further, job losses mount, and aggregate demand slips, driving monthly CPI prints lower through fall 2025. As a result, a high base from 2024 and a couple of soft readings in late 2025 are enough to push the 12-month CPI increase for November 2025 under the 2.73% November 2024 value. Tariff and wage pass-through prove to be mostly one-off, and core CPI decelerates by Q4 2025.
US Economic Statistics (Bureau of Labor.final_reasoning: Recent news and data show a mixed picture: inflation is currently above the 2024 mark (August inflation at 2.9%, core at 3.1%), driven in large part by tariff impacts, which now appear to be more entrenched in consumer prices. However, the labor market is deteriorating rapidly—large negative payroll revisions, weak hiring, and a rising unemployment rate point toward cooling demand and downside inflation risk in coming months. The Federal Reserve is beginning to cut rates, under pressure from both economic data and political actors, but markets and the Fed remain wary of stoking fresh inflation. Professional economic forecasts (e.g., CBO) suggest an annual 2025 average inflation rate of 3.1%, which would imply that absent major disinflation, the November 2025 print could be at or above the previous year’s 2.73%. That said, labor market weakness historically exerts strong downward pressure on inflation. Given the high current reading, softening economy, Fed cuts, and the possibility of base effects lowering YoY inflation with modestly weak monthly prints, I estimate the probability of a lower CPI in November 2025 than in November 2024 to be somewhat less than even but not extremely low. The base rate for annual CPI retracements during times of sharply rising unemployment is non-negligible, but with current prints elevated, the path to a 'Yes' resolution relies on quite rapid disinflation by late 2025—which is plausible, but not the most likely outcome by default. I assign a final probability of 35%, reflecting how the status quo (recently rising inflation) and explicit policy-induced price pressures make a higher November 2025 CPI slightly more probable, but labor market and base effect risks temper that.

US Policy Analysis (Congressional Budget.time_to_resolution: Approximately 2.5 months (as of 2025-09-15, question resolves with the release of November 2025 CPI, likely mid-December 2025)
US Policy Analysis (Congressional Budget.perspective_relevance: As an expert in US policy analysis with Congressional Budget Office (CBO) forecasting experience, I am familiar with macroeconomic forecasting methodologies, the lagged effects of fiscal and monetary policy, and how structural changes (tariffs, immigration, fiscal stimulus) influence inflation and labor markets. My expertise allows me to carefully parse the latest CBO projections, Fed guidance, and base rates for year-over-year CPI changes while weighing real-world uncertainty and political pressures.
US Policy Analysis (Congressional Budget.status_quo: If nothing changed, recent data shows the trajectory of year-over-year CPI inflation rising: August 2025's CPI is 2.9% versus 2.73% in November 2024, suggesting recent reacceleration driven by tariffs and supply-side pressures. However, both official forecasts (CBO, Moody’s) and historical base rates provide strong mean-reverting tendencies toward lower inflation in the medium term, especially with a cooling economy and rate cuts.

perspective_derived_factors.effect: Decrease probability for inflation falling: The CBO (as of Sept 2025) expects 2025 annualized CPI above Nov 2024 levels (projecting 3.1% for 2025, above Nov 2024's 2.73%), with improvement forecasted only for 2026 (2.4%). This is a strong bearish signal for inflation falling by Nov 2025.

Decrease probability for falling inflation: Trump's tariffs are now visibly impacting CPI (cars, clothing, furniture prices, etc.). Immigration reduction is further tightening the labor market and supporting wage growth, keeping inflationary pressure elevated through late 2025.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Monetary Policy: Fed Rate Cuts and Lagged Effects
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Mild increase: Rate cuts are imminent, but there is often a delay (6–18 months) before easier monetary policy substantially lowers annual CPI. Some downward force in late 2025 likely, but not enough to offset other upward drivers by November.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Labor Market Weakness and Demand Destruction
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Increase probability for falling inflation: Job creation has sharply collapsed (BLS revision down nearly 1M jobs), unemployment rising. If a recession scenario develops (as CBO and others warn), demand weakness could quickly cool inflation, especially toward year-end.

Increase probability: Historically, sustained increases in the 12m CPI to above 2.7–3% are uncommon outside of major shocks. The US generally reverts near the Fed’s target within a year (since the 1990s), unless supply shocks persist.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Recent CPI Momentum: Direction in Latest Data
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Decrease probability for inflation falling: As of August, inflation is clearly accelerating, and month-over-month numbers are above forecast (0.4% in August vs. 0.2% in July), suggesting CPI may be trending further above 2.73% as we approach November.

US Policy Analysis (Congressional Budget.no_scenario: Tariffs and immigration restrictions continue to drive up input and labor costs, pushing annual CPI above 3% y/y in November 2025. Despite rate cuts, the lag in monetary policy means inflation remains above the November 2024 mark. A mild recession may stall but not reverse these pressures by November's measurement.
US Policy Analysis (Congressional Budget.yes_scenario: The labor market decelerates more dramatically, with layoffs spreading, and consumer sentiment plunges in early autumn, collapsing demand faster than expected. Businesses compete more aggressively on price. Importers/retailers further absorb tariff costs as margins compress, and rapid Fed easing triggers a sharp move lower in sequential inflation readings, pulling the November 2025 level below Nov 2024.
US Policy Analysis (Congressional Budget.final_reasoning: CBO and mainstream forecasts, now incorporating Trump's tariffs and immigration reductions, point to CPI being higher (around 3.1%) in 2025 than the 2.73% of November 2024. Recent data confirms reacceleration of annual inflation and no sign of reversal. While the labor market is cooling fast and recession risks are mounting, and Fed cuts are on the way, the bulk of the disinflationary effect is expected to hit only in 2026. Historically, one-off tariff pass-through can fade, but political reality (reluctance of business to eat all costs, persistent policy uncertainty) and forecast consensus make it unlikely CPI will fall below last year’s reading by November. The strongest No signals are from the CBO forecast (my primary reference as a CBO forecaster), recent CPI gains, and the actual mechanism of tariffs and slower immigration. Some downside risk remains if the recession is deeper/faster than consensus models. I weight the No outcome at the higher end of justified probability, but not to 100% given economic uncertainty.

Macroeconomics (Phillips Curve).time_to_resolution: Approximately 2 months and 2 weeks (until release of November 2025 CPI, likely mid-December 2025)
Macroeconomics (Phillips Curve).perspective_relevance: As a macroeconomist specializing in the Phillips Curve, my unique perspective centers on analyzing the interplay between unemployment, labor market slack, and inflation. The Phillips Curve framework—especially in its modern, flattened incarnation—emphasizes how slackening demand and higher unemployment constrain wage and price growth, while recognizing that supply shocks (such as tariffs) and expectations play a critical role in the current environment. This perspective is especially pertinent under the confluence of labor market weakening, tariff-driven supply shocks, and evolving monetary policy.
Macroeconomics (Phillips Curve).status_quo: The 12-month percentage change in the US CPI as of November 2024 is 2.73%. Barring significant shocks, inflation has been trending modestly higher through mid-2025, with recent readings at/above 2.9%. The status quo, if nothing changed (trends continue), would be an inflation rate in November 2025 that is slightly above or near the November 2024 value, possibly near or above 3%.

perspective_derived_factors.effect: Increases the probability of a Yes (lower YoY CPI); rising unemployment, significantly weaker employment revisions, and tepid job creation point to slack that typically weighs on inflation.

Decreases probability of Yes; new and higher tariffs under Trump are showing up in prices, especially on goods (autos, food, clothing); historical data shows these effects often roll through CPI in the short-to-medium term.
Decreases probability of Yes, modestly; expected rate cuts can add to demand-side price pressures, yet given labor market slack, pass-through is likely reduced.

Neutral to moderate increase in probability of Yes; if there was an inflation uptick in late 2024 or early 2025, higher base reduces YoY growth in late 2025, mechanically aiding a lower reading, but this depends on the intra-year trajectory.

Increases probability of Yes; Fed and macro consensus increasingly sees tariff-driven CPI increases as one-off (level shifts), which means future YoY inflation returns closer to pre-shock path unless new shocks emerge.
Increases probability of Yes, modestly; most consumer/business and market-based inflation expectations remain anchored, suggesting little risk of an upward spiral.

Macroeconomics (Phillips Curve).no_scenario: Despite labor market weakness, supply-side price pressures (tariffs, higher import costs, immigration crackdowns reducing labor supply and pushing up wages) persist or intensify. The Federal Reserve’s response is judged as insufficiently early or forceful, or rate cuts stimulate demand more than anticipated, counteracting slack effects. Sticky shelter/Rent, food, or energy costs keep CPI elevated. November 2025 CPI YoY is at or above 2.73%.
Macroeconomics (Phillips Curve).yes_scenario: Labor market continues to deteriorate and unemployment rises to/above 4.5%. Weak wage growth, declining consumer demand, and business price resistance cause CPI inflation to slow. Tariff pass-through is limited by weak final demand, as suggested by softened PPI and businesses absorbing costs. Monetary easing fails to spark much new spending. November 2025 YoY CPI declines below the November 2024 rate of 2.73%.
Macroeconomics (Phillips Curve).final_reasoning: The current data present a mixed picture: headline inflation has risen in mid-2025, but primarily on the back of tariffs and sector-specific cost increases. The labor market, however, has turned sharply weaker than previously believed, with large downward revisions and a substantial rise in unemployment. The Phillips Curve relationship, while muted, is not dead: recent work shows that large and sudden surges in unemployment can exert significant downward pressure on CPI inflation after a lag. The news cycle demonstrates that the Fed is now more concerned with soft labor markets than runaway inflation, with a consensus for upcoming rate cuts. While there is a non-negligible risk that inflation remains sticky or is pushed up further by tariffs and fiscal stimulus, the overall dynamic now points to weakening aggregate demand overwhelming supply-side price shocks, especially as firms absorb costs and PPI shows signs of rolling over. The modal forecast is for CPI inflation to peak in late summer/fall 2025 and then drift lower by November, aided by base effects and labor market slack. However, risks from sticky categories and new policy shocks (tariffs, fiscal moves, or a sharp oil rebound) mean the probability cannot be extreme. Weighting all factors and base rates, I assess a roughly two-thirds chance (66%) that November 2025 CPI YoY will be below November 2024’s 2.73%.

Macroeconomics (Monetarist Theory).time_to_resolution: About 2.5 months (from 2025-09-15 to the CPI release for November 2025, typically reported mid-December 2025)
Macroeconomics (Monetarist Theory).perspective_relevance: As an expert in Monetarist Theory, I focus on how changes in money supply, interest rates, and central bank policy affect inflation dynamics. Monetarists consider the relationship between monetary policy, aggregate demand, and price levels as central. My expertise is particularly relevant because the question hinges on whether the Federal Reserve’s policy stance and broader macroeconomic adjustments—especially given shocks like tariffs and fiscal stimulus—will drive inflation higher or lower over a 1-year period.
Macroeconomics (Monetarist Theory).status_quo: Over the past year, US inflation (12-month CPI) has moved from ~2.7% in November 2024 to 2.9% in August 2025, with considerable attention on tariff-induced increases and recent rate cuts after a year-long hold. Traditionally, however, US inflation trends to persist at similar levels or revert gradually barring major shocks. The base rate for YoY CPI to decrease from one November to the next is a little above 50% in modern US history, but major macro events can tilt that probability.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Lagged effects of monetary policy (Fed rate cuts)
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Fed easing typically boosts aggregate demand with a lag, raising inflation, but the current environment—with high unemployment, weak labor markets, and cautious consumer activity—dilutes this effect. However, if the Fed cuts rates further into late 2025, monetary expansion could be inflationary by November 2025. Overall, I see this as slightly increasing inflation risk.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Tariff shocks and pass-through to consumer prices
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Tariffs have recently increased inflation, but both base effects and corporate price absorption mean the largest one-off price hikes may have already been realized. Unless new tariffs or escalations occur, their incremental impact will diminish by late 2025, shifting toward disinflationary as base effects roll off.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Labor market weakness and decelerating demand
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Labor market data is deteriorating sharply (record revisions, job growth <40k/month, rising jobless claims, unemployment above 4%). Monetarist theory and recent data both suggest falling real incomes and employment will drag on aggregate demand, creating downward pressure on inflation for the latter half of 2025.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Base effects: High CPI in late 2024/early 2025
perspective_derived_factors.effect: The sharp CPI increases from tariffs and pass-through in 2024 create a higher comparison base for November 2025. Even if month-on-month inflation remains moderate, the YoY change may naturally decline as earlier spikes roll off the calculation.

Fiscal stimulus (e.g., new tax cuts) can add to inflation by boosting disposable income; however, the CBO projects these effects are outweighed by contraction from tariffs and restricted immigration. The net effect is probably neutral to slightly inflationary, but not dominant.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Producer prices trend and input absorption
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Recent declines and below-expectation PPI suggest businesses are absorbing much of the tariff costs. If this continues, CPI inflation will face less upward pressure.

Macroeconomics (Monetarist Theory).no_scenario: A 'No' outcome (CPI is flat or higher YoY in Nov 2025) would likely result if: monetary easing triggers a rapid upswing in demand, consumer confidence rebounds, tariff or supply chain shocks reassert with second-round effects, fiscal stimulus is larger than expected, or oil/commodity prices spike. This could also happen if the labor market stabilizes or rebounds unexpectedly in Q4 2025.
Macroeconomics (Monetarist Theory).yes_scenario: A 'Yes' outcome (CPI is lower YoY in Nov 2025) follows if: employment continues deteriorating (as base rate/leading indicators signal), resulting in weak demand and negative real income growth; the major inflationary impact from tariffs has already been realized and rolls out of YoY comparisons; monetary/fiscal stimulus is too muted or offset by ongoing job losses; or if global commodity pressures ease. This is the Monetarist base case given disinflationary pressures described above.
Macroeconomics (Monetarist Theory).final_reasoning: Monetarist analysis and actual data both indicate that inflation is currently elevated due to earlier tariff shocks and recent supply-side constraints, but these are likely to be one-off factors whose effects will diminish by late 2025. The labor market is outright deteriorating, which will constrain aggregate demand and put downward pressure on consumer prices. Policy easing (rate cuts) may prevent outright deflation but is unlikely to fully offset contractionary demand-side forces given the magnitude of labor market weakness, especially within the 12-month window defined here. PPI data suggests cost pass-through is also waning. With high base effects from late 2024’s inflation, it is probable—even with some stickiness in core components (shelter, services)—that November 2025 will see a YoY CPI increase modestly below November 2024’s 2.73%. The main risk to this forecast is unexpectedly aggressive fiscal/monetary stimulus, commodity price spikes, or a reversal in labor market deterioration. Historical patterns and current conditions weigh in favor of a modest decline in CPI inflation.

Macroeconomics (New Keynesian Models).time_to_resolution: About 2 months (forecast date is 2025-09-15, resolution is based on CPI reported for November 2025, which will be available in December 2025).
Macroeconomics (New Keynesian Models).perspective_relevance: My expertise in New Keynesian models is highly relevant, as these models emphasize nominal rigidities, expectations, monetary policy transmission, and the interplay of aggregate supply and demand shocks—all critical for understanding the short-run dynamics of inflation. The current environment features tariff shocks (cost-push), labor market weakening (demand-side), and changing monetary policy stances (interest rate reductions under political pressure), each of which map directly to mechanisms analyzed in the NK framework.
Macroeconomics (New Keynesian Models).status_quo: As of August 2025, the 12-month CPI growth is at 2.9%, up from 2.7% in June and July; November 2024's CPI growth was 2.73%. The base rate for the question is slow-moving inflation, with YoY CPI rarely jumping by more than 1pp in either direction outside crisis episodes. The status quo (if nothing changed, i.e., if inflation simply moved sideways or with minor drift) would be 'No,' given the upward momentum and projections for tariffs to persistently affect prices.

perspective_derived_factors.effect: Increases the probability of a 'No' outcome. Trump's tariffs, especially the broad 10% and higher rates on key sectors, are currently feeding through to goods prices. While some firms are absorbing costs, articles and CBO/Moody's forecasts point to net upward pressure, especially as inventories run down and passthrough increases over months.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Labor market deterioration and demand slowdown
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Increases the probability of a 'Yes' outcome. The sharply weaker jobs reports, negative revision of job creation, rising unemployment (~4.3% and projected higher), and 'labor recession' create strong demand drag. Under NK models, nominal rigidities mean falling real incomes can reduce firms' pricing power, causing disinflation, especially in non-tradables.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Monetary policy—Federal Reserve rate cuts amid political pressure
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Ambiguous, but slightly raises 'No' probability. Rate cuts are stimulative, but are justified by weak demand. NK models tell us lower rates raise inflation through expectations and output, but if the economy is at or below potential, their effect may mostly stabilize output rather than generate much price pressure in the short run.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Base effects and recent inflation momentum
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Raises probability of 'No' outcome; recent CPI readings are accelerating (2.7% to 2.9%), and base effects mean that to get a lower November 2025 than November 2024, inflation will have to decelerate quickly, despite current policy and external shocks.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Goods vs. services and sectoral inflation composition
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Raises the probability of a 'No' outcome. Goods inflation is elevated via tariffs; services and rents are sticky downward. Shelter has been a persistent inflationary force. Ex-food/energy core is still over 3%. This makes sustained disinflation challenging.

Roughly neutral. Long-run inflation expectations are still well anchored. Some surveys and market measures show little reaction to tariffs; near-term expectations are creeping up but not dramatically. There is little evidence of runaway inflation mindsets.

Macroeconomics (New Keynesian Models).no_scenario: Tariffs continue to filter through to downstream prices, especially as importers finish burning through inventories and can't absorb further costs. Firms gradually increase pass-through, especially in consumer goods/apparel, and services inflation remains sticky due to labor costs. Even as the labor market weakens, the combination of cost-push factors and lagged pass-through sustains headline CPI at or above 2.7%—and possibly closer to 3%, as per CBO and Moody's projections. Monetary easing offsets the demand drag but is not enough to induce a sharp decline in inflation.
Macroeconomics (New Keynesian Models).yes_scenario: Labor market weakness intensifies: consumer spending falls more sharply than forecast, prompting a demand-led disinflation or even outright declines in discretionary goods/services prices. Pass-through of tariffs is less than expected as retailers cut margins and foreign suppliers absorb the shock. Fed rate cuts prove less effective than the political narrative assumes, and inflation surprises markets to the downside as it did in 2023. CPI for November 2025 posts a YoY gain below 2.73%.
Macroeconomics (New Keynesian Models).final_reasoning: Base rates and the structure of New Keynesian models—especially the persistent effect of cost-push shocks like tariffs and the slow-moving nature of services and shelter inflation—suggest that a rapid reversal of the recent CPI acceleration is unlikely. The labor market is weakening sharply, but disinflation from demand destruction usually takes time and is often muted when cost-push factors are present. Most professional forecasts (CBO, Moody's) expect YoY CPI to average above current levels in 2025, explicitly projecting 3–3.5% for the year—implying that, unless there is a rapid and unforecasted collapse in demand (which would be apparent by now), headline CPI in November 2025 will likely exceed 2.73%. While the Fed is cutting rates to offset the slowdown, monetary policy lags preclude immediate and substantial downward effect on inflation. The only plausible 'Yes' scenario is if ongoing demand collapse intensifies or if the tariff passthrough proves much smaller than expected. Given current data, the balance of factors tilts clearly toward a 'No' outcome, but with modest uncertainty around the magnitude of the disinflation stemming from labor market weakness.

Finance (Interest Rate Transmission).time_to_resolution: Approximately 2 months (until publication of November 2025 CPI, typically mid-December 2025)

Finance (Interest Rate Transmission).status_quo: Annual CPI inflation was 2.73% in Nov 2024. As of September 2025, the latest annual CPI print is 2.9% (August), with recent readings showing some upward movement after a period of cooling. The base case in such situations is persistence or slow, incremental change in inflation, often influenced by gradual macroeconomic shifts unless there is a major policy shock.

INCREASES probability. Tariffs imposed in early 2025 have begun to show up in prices (esp. autos, clothing, groceries), elevating inflation in the near term. perspective_derived_factors.effect: INCREASES probability. perspective_derived_factors.factor: Recent inflation momentum and pipeline price data (PPI, CPI details)
perspective_derived_factors.effect: DECREASES probability. Recent PPI prints have surprised to the downside and pipeline cost pressures are ebbing, signaling that August’s hotter CPI may be a blip rather than a trend. Some categories (medical care, recreation) are declining in price. This supports a view of peak inflation being near.

Finance (Interest Rate Transmission).no_scenario: Inflation remains sticky or rises further due to persistent tariff passthrough, commodity shocks, and/or fiscal stimulus. Job market stabilizes before winter or White House pressure leads the Fed to cut very aggressively, undermining credibility and reigniting inflation expectations. November 2025 CPI year-on-year change stays at or above 2.73%.
Finance (Interest Rate Transmission).yes_scenario: Tariff effects prove mostly one-off with little further upward pressure, while weak labor markets and fading consumer demand drive core and headline CPI lower as the lagged effects of September (and subsequent) rate cuts begin to show. PPI and import prices stay soft, and inflation returns to the low 2% range by November 2025. November 2025 year-over-year CPI is below 2.73%.
Finance (Interest Rate Transmission).final_reasoning: The strongest signals in recent data are the notable weakening in labor markets, the relatively mild actual passthrough of tariffs to CPI (firms absorbing much of the cost thus far), and an emerging downward trend in pipeline inflation (PPI, wholesale prices). These all point to lower demand-pull and cost-push inflation pressures into year-end. While headline CPI has ticked up recently (2.9% in August), core components are mixed and market/professional forecasts foresee a slowdown—CBO, Moody's, consensus economist estimates all suggest annual inflation moderates into early/mid-2026. Interest rate cuts now, and possibly again in Q4, will add disinflationary impulse with a lag, hitting full force just as CPI comparisons roll over November-to-November. Risks remain from tariffs and fiscal shock, but with consumer spending ebbing, job cuts mounting, and weaker pipeline pressures, odds favor inflation dropping below the Nov 2024 print by the comparison window. Assuming no major global commodity shock or policy misstep, the base rate plus recent data support a moderately confident 'Yes' forecast.

Finance (Inflation Expectations Hypothes.time_to_resolution: Approximately 2.25 months until November 2025 CPI data is fully available (assuming final data by mid-December 2025).

My framework weighs both current macroeconomic fundamentals and the expectations channel through which Fed credibility, labor market signals, and policy uncertainty propagate into inflation outcomes.
Finance (Inflation Expectations Hypothes.status_quo: Over the last year, US inflation has hovered slightly above the Fed's 2% target: the Nov 2024 12-month CPI was 2.73%. Current trajectory, with recent prints at 2.7-2.9%, would suggest mild upside risks to inflation, but not a surge; barring major shocks, inflation would stagnate or rise modestly from here.

perspective_derived_factors.effect: Raise probability of higher inflation in 2025 (i.e. No), as Trump’s tariffs are feeding into import and consumer prices, with further pass-through warned for late 2025.

Lower probability of higher inflation (i.e. Raises likelihood of Yes), as sharply deteriorating employment (job losses, rising claims, weak hiring) should dampen wage growth and aggregate demand, putting downward pressure on CPI sequentially.

Ambiguous. Near-term rate cuts signal the Fed’s shift to prioritizing growth/stabilization over inflation—risking a slight re-acceleration in inflation. This marginally raises the chance of Yes (inflation lower), but only modestly.

Raises the probability of a Yes outcome. With CPI running above 2.7% in late 2024 and early 2025, base effects could lead to softer YoY prints into late 2025 if sequential monthly readings stabilize or drop as the economy slows.

Finance (Inflation Expectations Hypothes.no_scenario: A No outcome materializes if tariff pass-through into retail prices, particularly in sensitive categories like cars, apparel, and groceries, is stronger and more persistent than anticipated. If sequential monthly inflation remains 0.2-0.4% for the rest of 2025 and/or if energy/food prices spike or wage growth surprises to the upside due to ongoing labor market tightness, the November 2025 YoY CPI will stay at or above November 2024’s 2.732%. Policy stimulus (tax cuts, fiscal expansion) could also add demand pressure, countering the labor softness.
Finance (Inflation Expectations Hypothes.yes_scenario: A Yes outcome occurs if the weakening labor market sharply restrains consumer spending and wage inflation, transmission of tariffs into final prices remains moderate (due to ongoing cost absorption by firms or margin compression), and energy/food price shocks are absent. If monthly CPI sequential gains weaken (0.1-0.2%) over autumn, the YoY measure falls below November 2024’s 2.73%. The Fed’s policy shift, by reassuring markets and anchoring medium-run expectations, could reinforce this dynamic.
Finance (Inflation Expectations Hypothes.final_reasoning: Base rates: Historically, US CPI rarely accelerates for more than 2–3 years post-shock without additional catalysts; the 2022–2023 spike was reversed in 2024, and current levels (2.7–2.9%) are not runaway but subject to upside risk from tariffs. However, there is mounting labor slack—a classic disinflationary force. Most forecasts (CBO, Fed) project modestly weaker inflation into 2026, with expectations (and survey data) remaining anchored. Recent data indicates that much of the tariff-induced inflation is a one-time level adjustment rather than persistent. Market-based long-run inflation expectations remain subdued; forward-looking measures suggest inflation should start to bend lower, especially if sequential price gains subside as the economy weakens. Nevertheless, risks remain from persistent pass-through of tariffs, policy uncertainty, and exogenous supply shocks. Taking these factors and the inertia of the status quo, I assign a moderate but not overwhelming probability (consistent with evidence and base rates for inflation reversal) that November 2025 CPI YoY will fall below November 2024.

Political Science (Political Business Cy.time_to_resolution: About 2 months (forecast date: 2025-09-15; question resolves upon release of November 2025 CPI print, which will be available in mid-December 2025)
Political Science (Political Business Cy.perspective_relevance: Political business cycle theory posits that policymakers, particularly around election cycles, may attempt to influence macroeconomic variables like inflation to achieve political goals. In the post-election period, President Trump is pressuring the Fed to lower rates, and his administration's policy mix includes fiscal stimulus (tax cuts), tariffs, and immigration restrictions. I am trained to evaluate the interplay of monetary and fiscal policy changes, policy lags, and the historical behavior of inflation, particularly in times of economic slowdown or political intervention.
Political Science (Political Business Cy.status_quo: The latest 12-month change in CPI (August 2025) is around 2.9%. If current trends continue, inflation would likely run close to—but potentially slightly above—the November 2024 level of 2.7%. The base rate for 12-month inflation falling over the following 12 months has historically been somewhat >50% when inflation is not high or accelerating, but policy and labor market shocks complicate matters.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Tariff policy and import cost pass-through
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Increases probability of higher inflation: Newly imposed tariffs are working their way through the economy, contributing to higher import prices for cars, clothing, and some other goods. While some firms have absorbed costs, producer price data and company guidance suggest more pass-through could occur, keeping CPI elevated and reducing the likelihood of a lower YoY print in Nov 2025.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Immigration clampdown and labor market tightness
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Increases probability of higher inflation: The reduction in the flow of foreign workers tightens labor markets, raises labor costs (especially in lower-wage sectors), and may sustain elevated services inflation despite economic cooling.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Weakening labor market and risk of economic slowdown
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Decreases probability of higher inflation: Unemployment is rising and job creation has sharply slowed, with unprecedented negative revisions. If the job market continues to cool or tips into recession, demand-side disinflation pressures will grow, possibly overcoming cost-push (tariff) factors. This could lower core inflation and drag headline CPI down by late 2025.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Monetary policy (Fed rate cuts and forward guidance)
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Mixed effect: The Fed is expected to begin cutting rates imminently, with possibly more reductions by year-end. While rate cuts can stoke demand and inflation, in practice, cuts during periods of labor market weakness often signal Fed concern that growth and inflation will decline, not rise (as per the political business cycle literature). The fact that rate cuts historically precede recessions should not be neglected.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Base rate/inertia and status quo bias
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Moderately increases probability of a lower print: Historically, when annual CPI is below 3% in a cooling economy, the odds favor further moderation rather than a sustained reacceleration, barring persistent cost shocks.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: One-off vs. persistent effect of tariffs
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Mixed effect: If tariff impacts are temporary "one-off" price level shifts, their inflation impact may fade by late 2025, lowering YoY CPI. However, if pass-through intensifies or is staggered, it can keep inflation sticky through November.

Increases probability of higher inflation: Tax cuts and stimulus add to aggregate demand and could offset some disinflation from labor market slack, as seen in recent CBO and Moody's projections raising inflation forecasts for 2025.

Slightly increases probability of higher inflation: Professional and institutional forecasts (CBO, Moody's) expect CPI inflation of 3% or above in 2025, which would mean a higher or similar print in November 2025 versus November 2024 (2.7%).

Political Science (Political Business Cy.no_scenario: Headline YoY inflation remains sticky at or above 2.7% through November 2025, due to continued pass-through from tariffs (especially as some cost absorption late in 2024 is unwound), along with fiscal stimulus (tax cuts) and labor cost pressure from immigration restrictions, offsetting the disinflationary impact of the weakening labor market. Under this scenario, CPI in Nov 2025 is equal to or higher than November 2024.
Political Science (Political Business Cy.yes_scenario: Weaker economic activity (unemployment rising, consumer spending slowing, negative job revisions, and potential onset of a mild recession) causes demand to fall sufficiently for disinflation to outweigh tariff/fiscal shocks. Tariff effects fade or are mostly one-off, and commodity prices stabilize or decline. The labor market's deterioration leads to core inflation approaching or undershooting 2.5%. November 2025 CPI is lower than November 2024.
Political Science (Political Business Cy.final_reasoning: The base rate suggests a modest probability of annual inflation declining year-over-year when the starting point is sub-3% and the economy is weakening. However, several unusual factors are at play: (1) powerful supply-side shocks from new tariffs and immigration policy, (2) pro-cyclical fiscal stimulus, and (3) increased uncertainty about monetary policy transmission in this unique context. The most recent data show a re-acceleration in CPI to 2.9% in August from 2.7% in June/July, with notable core and services stickiness tied to cost shocks, even as labor market indicators deteriorate significantly. Major forecasters (CBO, Moody's) expect 2025 annual inflation of 3.1–3.5%, suggesting risk that late-2025 CPI remains elevated relative to Nov 2024's 2.7% baseline. However, given the lagged effects of monetary policy, the sharpness of the labor market reversal, and the possible "one-off" nature of tariff pass-through (prices jump, then new base level), it would take only slightly weaker monthly prints from September–November to bring Nov 2025 YoY inflation below the previous year. The downside risk is a sudden disinflation leading into 2026, especially if recession materializes. Balancing all inputs—status quo, recent uptick, policy lags, and base rate bias toward moderation (but recognizing the real risk of sticky inflation)—my best estimate is that it is *slightly less likely than not* that November 2025 CPI will be below November 2024 CPI, but this is a high-uncertainty, close-to-even scenario. I assign a probability of 40%.

Political Science (Policy Uncertainty Th.time_to_resolution: Approximately 2.5 months (from Sept 15, 2025 to CPI release for November 2025, likely mid-December 2025)
Political Science (Policy Uncertainty Th.perspective_relevance: My expertise in Policy Uncertainty Theory is crucial here: policy-driven shocks (tariffs, labor/immigration policy, central bank independence) create second-order effects and raise macroeconomic forecast uncertainty. I bring an understanding of how shifts in administrative pressure on the Fed, unpredictable tariff pass-through, and political interference can elevate 'policy uncertainty' risk, biasing macro forecasts toward persistence in outcomes and volatility.
Political Science (Policy Uncertainty Th.status_quo: Inflation is rising, with the August 2025 CPI at 2.9% y/y, above the November 2024 baseline (2.73258%). The trend has been modestly upward since mid-2025, mainly due to tariffs, but labor market weakness is increasing. The default is for inflation in Nov 2025 to remain equal to or above Nov 2024 unless ongoing shocks (economic slowdown, policy response) can reverse current trends.

perspective_derived_factors.effect: Increases probability inflation in Nov 2025 remains at or above Nov 2024. However, extent and persistence may fade after initial adjustment period (one-time bump hypothesis), lowering effect over the next two quarters.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Labor Market Deterioration & Risk of Recession
